results.title: Sign Up for the Science Times Newsletter
results.abstract: Every week, we’ll bring you stories that capture the wonders of the human body, nature and the cosmos.

results.title: Among Seniors, a Declining Interest in Boosters
results.abstract: Americans over 65 remain the demographic most likely to have received the original series of vaccinations. But fewer are getting the follow-up shots, surveys indicate.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: Saul Pashkoff rolled up his sleeve before receiving his second dose of the Covid-19 vaccine at a senior-care facility on Staten Island, N.Y.
multimedia.copyright: Christopher Occhicone for The New York Times

results.title: Sleep Is a Science, but the Phillies Went With Their Gut
results.abstract: Despite a recommendation to stay the night in San Diego on Wednesday, Philadelphia’s road-weary players elected to get home as quickly as possible. So far, so good.

multimedia.caption: The Philadelphia Phillies appeared well-rested when Kyle Schwarber led off with a 405-foot home run on Friday in Game 3 of the National League Championship Series.
The Philadelphia Phillies appeared well-rested when Kyle Schwarber led off with a 405-foot home run on Friday in Game 3 of the National League Championship Series.
The Philadelphia Phillies appeared well-rested when Kyle Schwarber led off with a 405-foot home run on Friday in Game 3 of the National League Championship Series.

results.title: Beryl Benacerraf, 73, Dies; Pioneered the Use of Prenatal Ultrasound
results.abstract: A radiologist with an uncanny visual sense, she revolutionized the diagnosis of fetal abnormalities like Down syndrome.

multimedia.caption: Dr. Beryl Benacerraf in an undated photo. She struggled with reading because of dyslexia, but she was in her element with images.
Dr. Beryl Benacerraf in an undated photo. She struggled with reading because of dyslexia, but she was in her element with images.
Dr. Beryl Benacerraf in an undated photo. She struggled with reading because of dyslexia, but she was in her element with images.

results.title: A Vermont Town’s Water Official Resigns Amid Fluoridation Confusion
results.abstract: Kendall Chamberlin, the town’s water superintendent for over 30 years, said he had been lowering fluoride levels well below state guidelines for more than a decade.

multimedia.caption: Kendall Chamberlin at a Water and Sewer Commission meeting in Richmond, Vt., on Oct. 3. Mr. Chamberlin resigned as the water superintendent after admitting to lowering the fluoride levels in the town’s water.

Kendall Chamberlin at a Water and Sewer Commission meeting in Richmond, Vt., on Oct. 3. Mr. Chamberlin resigned as the water superintendent after admitting to lowering the fluoride levels in the town’s water.

Kendall Chamberlin at a Water and Sewer Commission meeting in Richmond, Vt., on Oct. 3. Mr. Chamberlin resigned as the water superintendent after admitting to lowering the fluoride levels in the town’s water.

results.title: In a Musical About Penicillin’s Inventor, Superbugs Take Center Stage
results.abstract: “The Mold That Changed the World” traces the life of the inventor of penicillin and offers a message: Don’t take antibiotics unless you really need them.
des_facet: The Mold That Changed the World (Play)

multimedia.caption: Jeremy Rose stars as Alexander Fleming, the physician who invented penicillin, in the musical “The Mold That Changed the World.”
multimedia.copyright: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times

results.title: A New Procedure Could Expand Reproductive Choices for Transgender Women
results.abstract: Retrieving viable sperm from men with low fertility and from people who have used estrogen therapy for years has been a challenge, doctors say. A new, less invasive technique has promise.

multimedia.caption: Chaya Rothschild, an andrologist at Maze Health in Manhattan, extracted sperm from an ejaculate sample in a process called extended sperm search and microfreeze.
multimedia.copyright: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Chaya Rothschild, an andrologist at Maze Health in Manhattan, extracted sperm from an ejaculate sample in a process called extended sperm search and microfreeze.

results.title: Biden Administration Offers Plan to Get Addiction-Fighting Medicine to Pregnant Women
results.abstract: Pregnant women are more likely to die of a drug overdose than the average woman of childbearing age, but less likely to be accepted for medication-based treatment.
org_facet: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration

multimedia.caption: Footprints of children born to women at Karen’s Place Maternity Center, an addiction recovery center in Louisa, Ky.
multimedia.copyright: Hilary Swift for The New York Times

results.title: Orionid Meteor Shower: How and When to Watch It Peak in Night Skies
results.abstract: Thursday night into Friday morning will be one of the dates scattered throughout each year when skywatchers can catch a meteor shower.

multimedia.caption: Orionid meteors streaking over Lebanon.
Orionid meteors streaking over Lebanon.
Orionid meteors streaking over Lebanon.

results.title: There’s Something in the Water in Virginia. Before You Say ‘Yuck,’ Wait.
results.abstract: A crucial aquifer is running low, so officials are pumping in treated sewage. It’s an increasingly common strategy as heavy demand and climate change strain water supplies.

multimedia.caption: A sediment sample taken this week in Newport News, Va. A planned recharge well at the site will inject additional treated wastewater into the Potomac Aquifer.
multimedia.copyright: Kristen Zeis for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: A sediment sample taken this week in Newport News, Va. A planned recharge well at the site will inject additional treated wastewater into the Potomac Aquifer.
multimedia.copyright: Kristen Zeis for The New York Times

results.title: M.I.T. Names a Duke Provost as Its New President
results.abstract: Sally Kornbluth, a cell biologist, is the second woman to lead the university. The provost, chancellor, dean of science and chair of corporation are also all women.

multimedia.caption: As Duke University provost, Sally Kornbluth said she “took steps to improve the environment for our faculty of color,” and to expand hiring.
As Duke University provost, Sally Kornbluth said she “took steps to improve the environment for our faculty of color,” and to expand hiring.
As Duke University provost, Sally Kornbluth said she “took steps to improve the environment for our faculty of color,” and to expand hiring.

results.title: Researchers Find Benzene and Other Dangers in Gas Piped to California Homes
results.abstract: A new study estimated that each year California gas appliances and infrastructure leak the same amount of benzene as is emitted by nearly 60,000 cars.

multimedia.caption: Angélica Ruiz and Drew Michanowicz are researchers at PSE Healthy Energy, a nonprofit institute that worked on the study.
Angélica Ruiz and Drew Michanowicz are researchers at PSE Healthy Energy, a nonprofit institute that worked on the study.
Angélica Ruiz and Drew Michanowicz are researchers at PSE Healthy Energy, a nonprofit institute that worked on the study.

results.title: A Fossil Museum Uses the Past to Reimagine Climate’s Future
results.abstract: As the La Brea Tar Pits & Museum undergoes a major redesign, its leaders hope it can do more to engage the public and educate visitors about the realities of climate change.

multimedia.caption: Only in Los Angeles could a 99 Cents Only Store sit next to a prehistoric landmark where greenish asphalt burps methane as tourists gawk.
multimedia.copyright: Tanveer Badal for The New York Times

results.title: Baseball History Is No Longer Written With Ash Bats
results.abstract: Invasive insects and batter preferences have led to the elimination of the wood that dominated the sport for generations. There may not be a single ash bat used in this postseason.

multimedia.caption: Babe Ruth was known for swinging an extra-large ash bat in his years of domination with the Yankees.
Babe Ruth was known for swinging an extra-large ash bat in his years of domination with the Yankees.
Babe Ruth was known for swinging an extra-large ash bat in his years of domination with the Yankees.

results.title: F.D.A. Panel Recommends Pulling Preterm Birth Drug From the Market
results.abstract: In use for 11 years, the drug Makena provided a test case of the agency’s controversial accelerated approval program. A post-market study showed the drug was not effective.

multimedia.caption: The preterm birth drug Makena has been in use for 11 years, but the F.D.A. recommended withdrawing it from the market. The decision was widely viewed as a test of the agency’s “accelerated approval” program.

The preterm birth drug Makena has been in use for 11 years, but the F.D.A. recommended withdrawing it from the market. The decision was widely viewed as a test of the agency’s “accelerated approval” program.

The preterm birth drug Makena has been in use for 11 years, but the F.D.A. recommended withdrawing it from the market. The decision was widely viewed as a test of the agency’s “accelerated approval” program.

results.title: These Doctors Admit They Don’t Want Patients With Disabilities
results.abstract: When granted anonymity in focus groups, physicians let their guards down and shared opinions consistent with experiences of many people with disabilities.

multimedia.caption: Lisa Iezzoni, a professor of medicine at Harvard, wanted to understand why people with disabilities kept reporting receiving substandard care. “I thought I needed to start talking to doctors,” she said.
multimedia.copyright: M. Scott Brauer for The New York Times

results.title: She Was Killed by the Police. Why Were Her Bones in a Museum?
results.abstract: Katricia Dotson’s remains were studied, disputed, displayed and litigated. Lost in the controversy was the life of an American girl and her family.

results.title: Britain Slashes Foreign Aid: ‘You Couldn’t Pick a Worse Time’
results.abstract: The nation is often the second-largest donor to groups working in poor countries to prevent and treat infectious diseases, and to provide reproductive health services to women.
org_facet: Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

multimedia.caption: A shipment of medical supplies, sent from the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office in Britain, arriving in New Delhi last year.
A shipment of medical supplies, sent from the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office in Britain, arriving in New Delhi last year.
A shipment of medical supplies, sent from the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office in Britain, arriving in New Delhi last year.

results.title: ‘Yankees, Go Home!’: Seoul Gets Squeezed Between the U.S. and China
results.abstract: The intensifying rivalry between Washington and Beijing is causing jitters in South Korea, where security ties and economic priorities are not always aligned.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

multimedia.caption: Residents and protesters blocked a road to the nearby Thaad base in Soseong-ri, South Korea, in September.

results.title: Four Questions to Ask Your Doctor Before Pelvic Surgery
results.abstract: To protect your sexual function, it’s vital to discuss your sex life, even if that feels awkward.

multimedia.caption: Because the clitoris is so interconnected with the local nerve supply, any surgery in the region poses some risk to sexual function.
multimedia.copyright: Shuran Huang for The New York Times

results.title: Lessons From a ‘Difficult Patient’
results.abstract: Sal was the kind of patient that doctors strive to avoid. But for one medical student, he provided an education in compassion.

results.title: Sadder but Wiser? Maybe Not.
results.abstract: A landmark 1979 study found that depressed people had a more realistic view of their influence over events. New research calls that into question.

multimedia.caption: The experiment involved a button and an occasionally flashing light, and participants were asked to assess if they were making the light flash when they pressed the button.
The experiment involved a button and an occasionally flashing light, and participants were asked to assess if they were making the light flash when they pressed the button.
The experiment involved a button and an occasionally flashing light, and participants were asked to assess if they were making the light flash when they pressed the button.

results.title: James A. McDivitt, Commander in Early NASA Triumphs, Is Dead at 93
results.abstract: In the 1960s, he led the first spacewalk mission and took part in the first crewed orbital flight of a lunar module.

multimedia.caption: James A. McDivitt, right, and Edward H. White 2d inside their Gemini 4 spacecraft awaiting liftoff in June 1965. The highlight of the four-day mission was a pioneering spacewalk.
James A. McDivitt, right, and Edward H. White 2d inside their Gemini 4 spacecraft awaiting liftoff in June 1965. The highlight of the four-day mission was a pioneering spacewalk.
James A. McDivitt, right, and Edward H. White 2d inside their Gemini 4 spacecraft awaiting liftoff in June 1965. The highlight of the four-day mission was a pioneering spacewalk.

results.title: Hair Straighteners May Pose a Small Risk for Uterine Cancer, Study Finds
results.abstract: A national study suggests a link to this particular cancer among women who reported frequent use of the chemical products.
org_facet: Journal of the National Cancer Institute

multimedia.caption: Light micrograph showing the spread of endometrial cancer cells.
Light micrograph showing the spread of endometrial cancer cells.
Light micrograph showing the spread of endometrial cancer cells.

results.title: Nigeria Floods Kill Hundreds and Displace Over a Million
results.abstract: The country is experiencing its worst floods in years, damaging homes, infrastructure and vast sections of farmland.

multimedia.caption: Vehicles on an unflooded road in Lokoja, Nigeria, on Oct. 13. The floods have partly or wholly destroyed farmland, infrastructure and 200,000 homes.
Vehicles on an unflooded road in Lokoja, Nigeria, on Oct. 13. The floods have partly or wholly destroyed farmland, infrastructure and 200,000 homes.
Vehicles on an unflooded road in Lokoja, Nigeria, on Oct. 13. The floods have partly or wholly destroyed farmland, infrastructure and 200,000 homes.

results.title: Half the World Has a Clitoris. Why Don’t Doctors Study It?
results.abstract: The organ is “completely ignored by pretty much everyone,” medical experts say, and that omission can be devastating to women’s sexual health.
